Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Detrital Zircon Record of California Arc Magmatism
Award.AbstractNarration:
Magmatic activity associated with the convergence and subduction of tectonic plates typically results in an array of volcanic complexes in the overriding plate and their subterranean plumbing systems. Given that volcanic systems and related intrusive igneous rocks form over tens of millions of years and commonly result in large volcanic edifices that are constantly subjected to erosion and burial, reconstructing the complete timing and geochemical evolution of volcanic systems can be difficult due to large gaps in the geologic record. In this study, the principal investigators are using a trace mineral commonly found in sedimentary rocks to help fill in gaps in our understanding of the geologic evolution of the volcanic and intrusive rocks of the Sierra Nevada volcanic arc of California. The object of this study is zircon, a mineral that commonly forms when igneous crystallize and its chemical structure contains radioactive elements that can be precisely dated by isotopic methods. In addition, other chemical elements provide a means by which the chemical evolution of the magmatic system may be revealed. Zircon is an unusually resistant mineral to chemical and mechanical breakdown in fluvial systems and it is commonly preserved in sedimentary rocks. Its abundance in many sedimentary rocks ensures that it can provide a record of volcanic and igneous rocks that have long since been eroded away by analyzing their chemistry and dating them. Analysis of such zircons thus provides a means by which the history of missing parts of volcanic arcs may be reconstructed, and this information can be used to unravel details of the tectonic and geodynamic evolution of the region in which the volcanic rocks were formed. In addition to the scientific objectives of the research, the project is contributing to important societal outcomes, including the training and mentoring of undergraduate students in a STEM discipline, as well as broadening of participation of underrepresented groups in science. The project represents a four-part collaboration between academic institutions of diverse type and educational mission.

The goal of this study is to combine age and trace element geochemistry of detrital zircons as proxy records for the evolution of the Mesozoic Cordilleran magmatic arc system. Zircon is an accessory mineral in a wide variety of igneous rocks, and is resistant to recrystallization during hydrothermal alteration and sedimentation. Detrital zircon can yield time-integrated records of magmatic systems. Zircon from in situ igneous rocks and detrital zircons derived from them together have the capability of recording both precise ages and variations in melt compositions in a long-lived magmatic environment, and when paired with studies of in situ igneous rock suites, detrital zircon records may provide a relatively more complete and detailed understanding of vertical and secular variations in partially eroded and incompletely exhumed magmatic systems. The principal investigators in this study will analyze populations of arc-derived detrital zircons in order to develop detrital proxy records of (1) the age and petrologic asymmetry of this arc that was constructed across a variable basement and (2) the geochemical variability of magmas through pulses and lulls in arc magmatism. Based on observations from an initial data set derived from a retroarc foreland basin, the principal investigators hypothesize that arc-derived detrital zircons can provide a temporally-controlled record of the evolution of average melt compositions over the full life span of the Cordilleran arc. They will study detrital zircon from a series of stratigraphic sections from within the forearc, intra-arc, and retroarc regions of the Cordilleran arc. Uranium-Lead (U-Pb) isotopic dates and trace element geochemistry of detrital zircons from these sections will allow them to evaluate the latitudinal and longitudinal variations in arc magmatism, and secular variations in zircon geochemistry will in turn help them test hypotheses regarding average melt compositions during magmatic pulses and lulls. These zircon age and geochemical records will also allow us to link magmatic pulses to tectonic events, such as episodes of crustal thickening within and beneath the arc. Thus these zircon geochemical data will constitute a useful new tool, both by describing the petrotectonic evolution of this long-lived arc system and by adding new geochemical constraints to detrital zircon provenance interpretations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Belts of volcanoes up to several thousand miles in length ("volcanic arcs") form where one or more of Earth?s tectonic plates slide ("subduct") beneath other plates. An excellent example is the presently active Andean volcanic chain along the west side of South America. The Andean arc results from the subduction of several plates that underlie the Pacific Ocean. These oceanic plates dive eastward beneath the South American continental plate at the rate of several inches per year. About 150 to 75 million years ago, a similar subduction process occurred along the western edge of North America. The latter subduction event produced a volcanic chain that extended continuously from Canada, through the United States, to Mexico. The North American volcanic belt was located close to the Pacific shoreline (within 100 miles), stood topographically high (elevations of 15,000 feet or greater), and served as a "continental divide" with respect to precipitation and river systems. That is, rain that fell on the western flank of the volcanic chain would have been channeled into rivers draining westward to the Pacific coast. In contrast, any precipitation that fell east of the crest of the chain would have flowed into a separate set of rivers draining eastward toward the interior of North America, with some of these rivers eventually reaching the Gulf of Mexico. However, about 75-50 million years ago, an unusual phase of subduction occurred which led to disruption of the volcanic chain in southern California. This event involved faulting and erosion of the mountains at the latitude of the present-day Mojave Desert. The result was a gap in the volcanic mountain belt about 200 miles in length that allowed the previously separate western and eastern river systems to interconnect.

The gap in the volcanic arc in southern California has been known for many years through geologic mapping and other lines of evidence. However, an appreciation of the implications for rivers systems is a more recent development. The evidence for river evolution is provided in large measure by dating of the mineral zircon (zirconium silicate) in sands deposited from those rivers. Zircon crystallizes in igneous rocks and can be used to date the time of formation of the rock. When rocks decompose through weathering processes, the degraded material may be transported by rivers and deposited as sediment far from the original source area. Grains of zircon carried in the sediment can potentially be matched to the sediment source area based on age.

Zircon age, alone, however, may not provide a unique match to source area, because igneous rocks of a given age may have a wide geographic distribution. In this project, we found that the detailed chemical composition of zircon can be used as an additional constraint on sediment source area. That is, igneous rocks with similar ages from different areas may exhibit different chemical compositions. Using both age and chemistry, zircon grains in sediments can thus be traced back to very specific matching source areas.

Based on the above zircon age and chemical tracer tool, we were able to confirm previous interpretations of river evolution in the southwestern United States. Specifically, prior to 75 million years ago, sediment deposited along the Pacific coast of southern California was apparently derived from short rivers, less than 100 miles long, that drained the western side of the ancestral Sierra Nevada. However, development of the arc gap in southern California beginning about 75 million years ago allowed several of the original short rivers to expand eastward across the former volcanic arc into southern Arizona and northwestern Mexico. The gap in the arc system through which these rivers passed is still evident in the modern landscape, although greatly modified related to development of the San Andreas fault system. In fact, the southern California volcanic arc gap was instrumental in the inception of the modern Colorado River. Without the arc gap, the Colorado River may never have reached its outlet to the Pacific Ocean. Likewise, without the break in the arc, there might be no Grand Canyon.

In addition to the scientific results, this project provided an intensive research experience for two undergraduate students from Northern Arizona University. The students participated in a nine-day workshop and field trip in southern California that brought together collaborators from four universities involved in the project, conducted field work in southern Utah, determined the chemistry of zircon grains at Stanford University, and presented their results at a national meeting of the Geological Society of America.
